Grady Locklear
Copywriter, Morillas Brand Design — Barcelona
Apr 14

The Future of Getting Around

Someone older than me was talking about innovation. He recalled the sci-fi visions of bubble cities and flying cars from his childhood. It was a beautiful dream. Of course, those flying cars never became reality. And they never would, he said, because of the challenges of piloting airborne vehicles.

He was confident it couldn’t ever happen.

But I think it will — and soon. Technologies are emerging that are going to make self-flying drone transportation a reality. And that’s only the beginning of the cool part. Getting around is going to be changing quickly. Here’s what I see playing out during the 20s.

We won’t need to travel as much

This may seem obvious, but let’s catalogue the ways. Do you work from home? Many people do — more than one in three Americans. And remote working is a growing trend. More jobs are being automated, from customer service to manufacturing and everything in between.

As physical jobs continue being phased out, knowledge workers will be increasingly prevalent. What does that mean? No more need for physical offices (which means less overhead for businesses). Since remote workers are more productive anyway, this is a win-win-win for everybody.

Alright, so the morning commute is going away. Thank goodness. Now let’s look at the domestic side of life.

Need to go shopping? Not for long. Grocery delivery is all the rage. More than a quarter of British people use online grocery shopping monthly. Globally, online grocery shopping is a multi-billion dollar industry and is projected to grow 73% by 2020. This trend will only be accelerated by the announcement of the Amazon Go shopping experience.

Before long, your fridge will simply order more food for you whenever you need it.

What about when you run out of household products like laundry detergent? Amazon Dash buttons for days! You’re not going to run out of basic things in a connected home where the smart appliances order their own refills.

Courier services like Postmates are seeing a lot of success too. No more need to drive to the corner store for any random things. There are bound to be some rocky starts, but this clearly is only the beginning. It’ll continue getting cheaper and more effective.

Soon, all of these services will be connected by AI personal assistants. What that means is the next generations of Amazon Echo, Google Home, Apple Siri and Microsoft Cortana will be competing to be your AI sidekick in charge of everything. Note that each of these providers already offer smartphones, tablets and other electronics. Your AI assistant will exist in the digital cloud, available everywhere you go: on your smartphone, in your home, in your car… think about the ways this will radically simplify transportation.

If you need a ride, ask your assistant and it’ll summon a nearby self-driving car to pick you up in moments. Matter of fact, most of the time you won’t have to ask. Your AI assistant will check your schedule and have a car waiting for you before you think to ask for it. That’s the power of predictive / anticipatory computing.

Anything else?

So, how about the other reasons we leave the house? Entertainment? It’s digital — thanks, Netflix. That entertainment giant, along with the likes of Amazon Prime, are continuing to make the theater experience obsolete.

You’ll start watching a show or movie in your home, continue watching on your device as you step outside, and finish the episode in the car. No need to drive to a cinema.

And what’s going to happen as virtual reality environments take over? You can bet there will be VR universes where you can meet your friends and experience the most exotic and stimulating places anyone can imagine, embodied by a sexy avatar instead of your regular meat-suit. And you won’t be wearing clunky VR headsets by the way. It’ll be hologram technology. So you and your friends will connect with each other from your separate living rooms, which will be virtually transformed into a shared environment they can all join from wherever they are.

Can you think of other reasons people need to travel? School? Yes. More on that later. Hitting the gym? Meeting up with friends? Concerts? Dating? Art galleries? Family reunions? Sightseeing? OK, sure. We’ll get to those more leisurely topics. But first let’s get even more futuristic.

Drone jetpacks are totally going to happen

Business Insider pointed out last year that drones are going to be carrying people before long. This concept will be essentially the same as the flying car idea, if not better. How about a super-cool quadcopter from China that can carry a single passenger for 23 minutes in the air? Already exists. Breakthroughs like this prompted Forbes to ponder last year which type of flying technology will dominate the air. It’s not even a question of “if” anymore.

Think of how far drone technology has come in recent years. Not long ago it was revolutionary to think of drones on movie sets. Now you can go kitesurfing with them.

As renewable energy develops, and battery storage capacity continues to increase, it won’t be long before drones can carry a person’s weight for significant distances. Check out this drone-like flyer that will be in prototype mode before the end of 2017.

Of course, learning to pilot one of these safely would be tricky. But you probably won’t have to. They’ll be on autopilot. BAE Sytems tested an autonomous aircraft system that piloted itself more than 300 miles. The goal is to have fully autonomous commercial flights by 2020. Here’s a piece by the Times about the future of pilotless flight.

It’s likely that this sort of automated technology would work for smaller aircraft. In fact, self-flying personal craft would be more attractive to regulatory agencies such as the FAA. Human unpredictability has been a headache, resulting in strict regulations on drones. Fully autonomous personal aircraft wouldn’t need to be as strictly controlled.

Autonomous, self-driving vehicles will be ubiquitous

After it drops Mom off at her office, the family vehicle will head back home to pick up the kids. Dad works remotely from his virtual studio, so he shuttles the children into the car and waves them off to the STEM charter school.

Why is it a charter school, you might ask? Because I think education is primed for a revolution. This is going off topic, but it stands to reason that education will become smaller. Smaller in the sense of personalization and customization, with lessons adapted to match learning styles and specializations. I imagine the concept of classes sorted by year doesn’t have a future — students will be grouped by ability and by career track. Rather than having a single group of classmates, they’ll find themselves attending specific classes with smaller, individualized groups. Large-scale, generic solutions are not appealing to adults, and that mode won’t last long in childhood education either. Whether it’s trade schools, charter schools or another option, I think school is going to look a lot different in the next decade.

Anyway, back to transportation. Self-driving vehicles will rule the road by the middle of the 20s. Trucking will be automated. Buses will be automated. And self-driving cars will be the industry norm very soon.

It’s not Silicon Valley headlining this trend, either. Detroit is taking huge strides in driverless tech. China is bringing the heat in the self-driving, electric car race. Japan wants Tokyo to be full of automated vehicles in time for the 2020 Olympics. How is that going to look?

More about automated bus lines and metros

In cities, metro systems and bus lines will continue to be a transportation staple through the 20s. They won’t be driven by people, but they will be automated for efficiency. And they won’t be as crowded. For example, smart data will help predict when traffic is likely to surge (as it does during sporting events and holidays) and increase the frequency of buses and metros accordingly.

Metro and bus lines will continue to be the backbone of metropolitan transportation at least through the end of the 20s. But you won’t find yourself alone on a train or bus. That’s not efficient.

Airlines might use big data to avoid overbooking, which could reduce instances of beating their customers.

Ride sharing will be the norm

Car ownership is going to be mostly a rural or deeply suburban thing. City dwellers will find it much more convenient to use ride-sharing services. Private driving experiences will still be available, of course. But sometimes people will literally be packed into shared cars — as with Volkswagen’s latest self-driving concept, which is like a sofa on wheels.

When you’re not in a car, you might be sharing a bike. Don’t be surprised to see these systems crop up for outdoor equipment such as kayaks, snowboards, boats, ATVs, snowmobiles and other gear.

You can see where this trend is going by watching where the auto giants are investing. Toyota and Uber are teaming up on a ride-sharing program. General Motors already launched a ride-sharing service called Maven in 2016. Toyota and other automotive giants are investing in ride-sharing programs too. If you live anywhere near a city, you may literally never buy a car again.

Universal availability will make taxis obsolete

People who own self-driving cars will typically enroll them in ride-sharing programs. It’s similar to the way AirBnB lets people share their homes. When your self-driving car isn’t needed, it will be available to prowl the street and be hailed by people who need a ride. This sort of service will be widespread in the mid 20s.

The sharing economy is only just beginning to take hold, and it’s going to continue to revolutionize industries from top to bottom. If the taxi industry was worried about the surging popularity of Uber and Lyft, this trend should be terrifying.

Individualized mass transit is where this is all trending. Smaller vehicles, more modes of transport, highly specific destinations — all on a mass scale. We’ll be able to get from Point A to Point B through any combination of vehicles, with our connected AI assistants personalizing the travel experience as soon as we step aboard.

Travel will be more about pleasure

With transportation becoming less of a need, traveling for urbanites is going to be about the non-essentials. With alternative energy continuing to become cheaper and more accessible, I envision travel as more about scenery and experience. Even considering the rise in virtual tourism, nothing quite replaces the real thing.

It’s already becoming more mainstream to wander into space. SpaceX, Blue Origin (Amazon, again), Virgin Galactic…

Side note: while commercial spaceflight will be cool, space mining will become a major corporate race with extensive government funding. Keep an eye on that, because it might take off by the late 20s and that may lead to advances in space travel. Maybe even artificial structures orbiting the planet, accessible by space elevator. But that’s down the road a bit.

So if personal vehicles go on the decline; with individualized mass transit taking over, what will happen to the airline industry?

Hyperloops will reduce domestic air travel

There are strong indications that commercial air travel won’t look the same in 10 or 15 years. Airlines that neglect to invest in nascent forms of transportation — as auto-makers are now — will not be around in a decade.

Imagine this scenario in five years: a ride-sharing service from an auto manufacturer like Ford purchases parts of several major U.S. airline conglomerates.

Naturally, international flights aren’t going to slow down much. And flights will be available to smaller cities for a long time to come. So air travel isn’t going to die, but it’ll look a lot different. Keep in mind that air travel will be self-piloted. The biggest challenge to the industry is going to come from pneumatic tubes on the ground, though. So let’s talk about hyperloops.

Hyperloop technology will be far more energy efficient than aircraft, not to mention safer, faster and more comfortable. I wouldn’t be surprised to see a west-coast hyperloop from Seattle to San Diego fully functioning by 2028. (Edit: as I’m writing this, these plans are now in the works).

Hyperloops won’t replace high-speed rail travel in Europe and Asia for a long time, but I think there will be some in development by the end of the next decade.

Smart cities will smoothify it all

Smart cities are going to make the urban experience a lot nicer. Connecting everything, including traffic patterns, parking, lighting, utilities, the energy grid… imagine streetlights that deliver super-fast wireless internet through LiFi. Oh wait, you don’t have to imagine it, because it’s already happening in Dubai.

Cars will charge themselves as they drive. This sort of system has been in testing for years already.

Getting from place to place will become much easier as long as you have a smartphone (or whatever replaces smartphones… Maybe embedded technology or wearables will upend the smartphone market in the near future).

One way or another, customized biometric access such as fingerprint readers, retinal scanners, or similar technology, will be essential. That’s because the next few generations of smart devices will have so much vital information connected to them. Even our brains.

Am I missing any trends on the topic of getting around? Let me know what you think.
